title: Is different timeline a different universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: Time is a measurement of change. It is a human “invention” which guides human experience, observation, investigation and speculation. Although time is predominantly thought of as linear, it is actually a measurement of moving from one point (point A) to another point (point B). The paths that can be taken between A and B are infinite. The events that can unfold during this movement are also unlimited. “Timeline” implies linear time. “Universe” to me implies a delineation (a part) of “Creation” (the totality of everything). Does this imply a hierarchy (solar systems or star systems within galaxies within universes within cosmoses within Creation)? Assumptions made that everyone knows and agrees what the term “universe” means(or what the elements of Creation are and mean or how elements of Creation relate) are false. Maybe within certain groups (or schools) there may is agreement. But generally, there is a lot of room for misconception, misunderstanding, and confusion. This situation has become compounded by “science fiction” and cult fantasies. And even if there were total agreement, the “convention” adopted would be only one way of breaking down Creation into parts for the purpose of discussion in attempts to understand it. So, first we must begin with a point A and we acknowledge we are an “observer” at point A. Where is point B (the point where the timeline of interest originates)? g This point, if real and if found, gives a location relative to point A and raises the question, “Is it worth tracing this discovered timeline until it reveals its destination?” And “At that destination, at this new point B, how does it relate to point A?” By doing something like what I have given, you can be true to the “concept” of time and maintain its importance. You then apply your definition of “universe” and decide whether you are in a different universe or not. I find these types of exercises tedious. They are characteristic of scientific investigation through the application of scientific conventions. What does it really matter if there is more than one universe or what universe you are in? Time is a human “concept” and is the “glue” that holds scientific monuments together. I am in favor of exploring the miracles and majesty of Creation and the Creative process.  But some of the concepts and conventions erected by man are too stubbornly held, applied, and endeared.
